feed.title: Combined summary - Adding New BIP Editors

entry.title: Combined summary - Adding New BIP Editors
entry.summary:
The recent discussions within the Bitcoin Development Mailing List have centered on proposed changes to the Bitcoin Improvement Proposal (BIP) process. These changes aim to shift the responsibility of BIP editors from evaluating the technical merits of proposals to ensuring their relevance and adherence to formal criteria. This adjustment is designed to alleviate the burden on editors, allowing the broader Bitcoin community to take on a larger role in technical evaluations, thereby expediting the review process and enhancing inclusivity.
The dialogue also touched on operational aspects of handling BIPs, noting that individuals with basic GitHub knowledge can propose amendments by directly engaging with authors, streamlining modifications without requiring special permissions. Yet, challenges such as the timely assignment of numbers to new BIPs and the integration of approved changes highlight the need for additional BIP editors to overcome these bottlenecks.
A significant point of contention arose around the governance of the BIP repository, especially concerning the roles of mailing list moderators and BIP editors. Concerns were raised about potential conflicts of interest and inefficiencies due to overlapping responsibilities between these roles. The discussion included considerations for archiving the current BIP repository to facilitate decentralized management, although the value of a unified repository for maintaining a centralized reference for ease of community access was also acknowledged.
The conversation underscored the importance of recruiting more editors to assist with the BIP review and management process. It suggested broadening the editorial team to include both developers, like Jon Atack and Roasbeef (with some reservations about Roasbeef’s suitability), and non-developers such as Seccour and Greg Tonoski, to assess the feasibility of diversifying the team’s composition. Luke Dashjr's involvement in selecting new BIP editors was mentioned, reflecting the community's trust in his judgment for filling these pivotal positions.
Furthermore, the process of appointing new editors for the BIPs emphasizes maintaining the integrity of the BIP numbering scheme and the overall development direction of Bitcoin. Kanzure and RubenSomsen were nominated for their contributions to Bitcoin and their ability to uphold its technical and community standards. Their expected roles as BIP editors aim to enhance the repository's management and evolution, demonstrating a collective commitment to Bitcoin’s ongoing improvement and innovation.
